questions.question: A $5.0\text{ kg}$ block rests on a horizontal table with a coefficient of static friction $\mu_s = 0.4$. What is the maximum static friction force? (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)
A $2.0\text{ kg}$ box slides across a floor where the coefficient of kinetic friction $\mu_k = 0.3$. What is the magnitude of the kinetic friction force? (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)
A block is on a horizontal surface. If the normal force is $50\text{ N}$ and the sliding friction is $10\text{ N}$, what is the coefficient of kinetic friction $\mu_k$?
A $2.0\text{ kg}$ ball is thrown vertically upward. Ignoring air resistance, what is the net force acting on the ball while it is in the air? (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Only force acting is weight: $F_{net} = mg = 2.0 \times 9.8 = 19.6\text{ N}$ downward.

questions.question: A person pushes a $50\text{ kg}$ crate with $150\text{ N}$ of force. If the crate moves at a constant velocity, what is the coefficient of kinetic friction $\mu_k$? (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)

A 8.0 kg aluminum crate is sitting at rest on a flat warehouse floor. The coefficient of static friction ($\mu_s$) between the aluminum and the floor is 0.62, while the coefficient of kinetic friction ($\mu_k$) is 0.44. Calculate the minimum horizontal force required to set the crate in motion. (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)

A 8.0 kg aluminum crate is sitting at rest on a flat warehouse floor. The coefficient of static friction ($\mu_s$) between the aluminum and the floor is 0.62, while the coefficient of kinetic friction ($\mu_k$) is 0.44. What is the frictional force on this object as it moves? (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)

A 8.0 kg aluminum crate is sitting at rest on a flat warehouse floor. The coefficient of static friction ($\mu_s$) between the aluminum and the floor is 0.62, while the coefficient of kinetic friction ($\mu_k$) is 0.44. What force must be applied to the object to keep it moving at constant velocity? (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Constant velocity ⇒ $F_{app} = f_k = 34.5\text{ N}$ (from previous question).

questions.question: A 1,500 N motorcycle locks its brakes and slides along a slick asphalt track. If the track is perfectly level, what is the magnitude of the kinetic friction force acting on the motorcycle? (Assume the coefficient of kinetic friction $\mu_k$ is 0.42).

A sled is being towed across a level snow-covered field at a steady velocity. A horizontal tow rope exerts a constant pull of 85 N on the sled. If the coefficient of kinetic friction ($\mu_k$) between the sled and the snow is 0.12, what is the total weight of the sled? (Use $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Steady velocity ⇒ $F_{app} = f_k = 85\text{ N}$. $f_k = \mu_k F_N$ ⇒ $85 = 0.12 F_N$ ⇒ $F_N = 708.3\text{ N}$. On level surface, weight = $F_N = 708\text{ N}$.

scoreMessages.70: Good work! Review the relationship between normal force and friction.
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing. Focus on using $f_k = \mu_k F_N$ and $f_{s,max} = \mu_s F_N$.
scoreMessages.0: Let's review. Study how to calculate normal force and apply friction formulas.
